_**Now You See Me**_ is a 2013 American [heist](/wiki/Heist_film "Heist film")
[thriller film](/wiki/Thriller_film "Thriller film") directed by [Louis
Leterrier](/wiki/Louis_Leterrier "Louis Leterrier") and written by [Ed
Solomon](/wiki/Ed_Solomon "Ed Solomon"), [Boaz Yakin](/wiki/Boaz_Yakin "Boaz
Yakin"), and Edward Ricourt. The film features an [ensemble
cast](/wiki/Ensemble_cast "Ensemble cast") of [Jesse
Eisenberg](/wiki/Jesse_Eisenberg "Jesse Eisenberg"), [Mark
Ruffalo](/wiki/Mark_Ruffalo "Mark Ruffalo"), [Woody
Harrelson](/wiki/Woody_Harrelson "Woody Harrelson"), [Isla
Fisher](/wiki/Isla_Fisher "Isla Fisher"), [Dave Franco](/wiki/Dave_Franco
"Dave Franco"), [Mélanie Laurent](/wiki/M%C3%A9lanie_Laurent "Mélanie
Laurent"), [Michael Caine](/wiki/Michael_Caine "Michael Caine"), and [Morgan
Freeman](/wiki/Morgan_Freeman "Morgan Freeman"). The plot follows an
[FBI](/wiki/FBI "FBI") agent and an [Interpol](/wiki/Interpol "Interpol")
detective who track a team of illusionists who pull off bank heists during
their performances and reward their audiences with the money, attempting to
bring them to justice. This is the first installment of a
[series](/wiki/Now_You_See_Me_\(film_series\) "Now You See Me \(film
series\)").

The film premiered in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") on
May 21, 2013 before its official release in the United States on May 31, 2013
by [Summit Entertainment](/wiki/Summit_Entertainment "Summit Entertainment").
The film received mixed reviews from critics but became a box office success,
grossing $351.7 million worldwide against a budget of $75 million. The film
won the Favorite Thriller Movie at the [People's Choice
Awards](/wiki/40th_People%27s_Choice_Awards "40th People's Choice Awards") in
2014 and also received nominations for the [Empire Award for Best
Thriller](/wiki/Empire_Award_for_Best_Thriller "Empire Award for Best
Thriller") and the [Saturn Award](/wiki/Saturn_Award "Saturn Award") for Best
Thriller Film and [Best Music](/wiki/Saturn_Award_for_Best_Music "Saturn Award
for Best Music"). A [sequel](/wiki/Now_You_See_Me_2 "Now You See Me 2") was
released on June 10, 2016.

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Now_You_See_Me_\(film\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

Four [stage magicians](/wiki/Magic_\(illusion\) "Magic \(illusion\)"), J.
Daniel "Danny" Atlas ([Jesse Eisenberg](/wiki/Jesse_Eisenberg "Jesse
Eisenberg")), Merritt McKinney ([Woody Harrelson](/wiki/Woody_Harrelson "Woody
Harrelson")), Henley Reeves ([Isla Fisher](/wiki/Isla_Fisher "Isla Fisher")),
and Jack Wilder ([Dave Franco](/wiki/Dave_Franco "Dave Franco")), are each
given a [tarot card](/wiki/Tarot_card "Tarot card") that leads them to the
same empty New York City apartment where they find information from an unknown
benefactor.

A year later, the four have their first major performance as the Four Horsemen
in an elaborate Las Vegas show funded by insurance magnate Arthur Tressler
([Michael Caine](/wiki/Michael_Caine "Michael Caine")). Their final trick
appears to transport one of the audience members to the vault of his bank, the
Crédit Républicain in Paris, where stacks of new euro bills are stored. At the
magicians' command, the fans in the vault activate, drawing the bills into the
vents and then showering the Las Vegas crowd with them. The euros are shown to
be real, and the vault in Paris is found to be empty of its recent shipment of
euros. [FBI](/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation "Federal Bureau of
Investigation") agent Dylan Rhodes ([Mark Ruffalo](/wiki/Mark_Ruffalo "Mark
Ruffalo")), and [Interpol](/wiki/Interpol "Interpol") agent Alma Dray
([Mélanie Laurent](/wiki/M%C3%A9lanie_Laurent "Mélanie Laurent")), are then
partnered to investigate the Horsemen. The two question the magicians but have
no evidence to hold them. Dylan and Alma turn to Thaddeus Bradley ([Morgan
Freeman](/wiki/Morgan_Freeman "Morgan Freeman")), a former magician who now
makes money by explaining the tricks behind magic acts. Thaddeus demonstrates
how the Horsemen used a mock vault under the Las Vegas stage and says that the
group must have stolen the money in Paris before it arrived at the bank,
replacing it with [flash paper](/wiki/Nitrocellulose "Nitrocellulose") that
left no evidence.

Dylan, Alma, and Thaddeus follow the Horsemen to their next show in New
Orleans, where their final trick appears to transfer millions of dollars from
Tressler's private accounts to those in the audience, made up of people that
were denied insurance claims by Tressler's company in the wake of [Hurricane
Katrina](/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina "Hurricane Katrina"). Dylan and Alma attempt
to apprehend the four, but the magicians elude arrest. Tressler hires Thaddeus
to expose the Horsemen in revenge for the loss of his money. Alma investigates
the Horsemen and determines they are connected to a group called the Eye, a
small group of magicians that claim to have access to real magic. She finds
out one of the Eye's members, Lionel Shrike, had previously been exposed by
Thaddeus but died in a locked-safe escape trick he was performing in an
attempt to regain his standing. Alma suspects a fifth person is aiding the
Horsemen.

Alma's research leads the FBI to the New York City apartment. When they raid
it, three of the Horsemen escape while Jack recovers numerous documents and
then leads the authorities on a high-speed car chase. Jack loses control of
his car, causing it to flip and catch fire. Dylan is unable to save Jack, but
manages to recover the papers, pointing to the Horsemen's next planned crime,
stealing millions of dollars in cash out of a large safe of the Elkhorn
company. Dylan, Alma, and Thaddeus find the safe has already been stolen, and
when they track it down, its contents have been replaced with balloon animals.
The Horsemen broadcast they will perform their final show that night at [5
Pointz](/wiki/5_Pointz "5 Pointz"), inviting the public to attend. The FBI and
police converge on the scene and amid the chaos search for the Horsemen. The
remaining Horsemen appear to the crowd, giving their fans a farewell and a
message about an ulterior purpose, and then run to jump off a roof; Dylan
attempts to shoot them but Alma holds him back. The three jump, turning into a
shower of money over the crowd. The money is counterfeit, but the audience's
race to collect it prevents the authorities from tracking the real Horsemen.

After the show, Thaddeus walks to his car, only to find it full of the money
stolen from the Elkhorn safe. Assumed to be the fifth Horseman, he is
arrested. Dylan speaks to Thaddeus in jail, where Thaddeus slowly comes to
realize that Alma's theory was correct, and Dylan was the fifth Horseman.
Dylan quietly walks away, leaving Thaddeus shouting "Why?". Elsewhere, the
Horsemen (including Jack, who had faked his death using a duplicate car and an
already-dead body) meet at the carousel in Central Park, and use their tarot
cards to turn it on. Dylan arrives and welcomes the four to the Eye.

Later, at the [Pont des Arts](/wiki/Pont_des_Arts "Pont des Arts"), Dylan
meets with Alma and reveals he is Shrike's son. He brought the Horsemen
together to get retribution for his father's death: the Elkhorn Safe Company
for providing a faulty safe that led to the accident; Thaddeus for humiliating
and impoverishing his father and forcing him to try the new trick to regain
his standing; and the Crédit Républicain and Tressler's insurance companies
for failing to pay out life insurance on Shrike afterwards. Alma, who has come
into a romantic relationship with Dylan, decides not to turn him in. She takes
a lock and a key that Dylan produces, attaching the lock among the other [love
locks](/wiki/Love_lock "Love lock") on the railing and throwing the key into
the [Seine](/wiki/Seine "Seine").

##
Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Now_You_See_Me_\(film\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

  * [Jesse Eisenberg](/wiki/Jesse_Eisenberg "Jesse Eisenberg") as J. Daniel "Danny" Atlas / [The Lover](/wiki/The_Lovers "The Lovers"): An arrogant illusionist and [street magician](/wiki/Street_magic "Street magic"), and the ostensible leader of the Four Horsemen.
  * [Mark Ruffalo](/wiki/Mark_Ruffalo "Mark Ruffalo") as Dylan Rhodes-Shrike,[4] an FBI agent struggling to capture and bring the Four Horsemen to justice for their unique heist agenda. In the outcome, he is revealed to be an illusionist, a member of the Eye himself, Lionel Shrike's son and the plotter of the entire heist mission.
  * [Mélanie Laurent](/wiki/M%C3%A9lanie_Laurent "Mélanie Laurent") as Alma Dray,[4] a French Interpol agent who is partnered up with Dylan Rhodes to investigate the Four Horsemen.
  * [Woody Harrelson](/wiki/Woody_Harrelson "Woody Harrelson") as Merritt McKinney / [The Hermit](/wiki/The_Hermit_\(Tarot_card\) "The Hermit \(Tarot card\)"): A [hypnotist](/wiki/Hypnosis "Hypnosis"), [mentalist](/wiki/Mentalism "Mentalism"), and a self-proclaimed psychic. Originally more famous in his youth, his manager brother absconded with all his money, leaving McKinney with a long hard trek back to his former glory. Middle-aged, McKinney is the oldest of the Four Horsemen.
  * [Isla Fisher](/wiki/Isla_Fisher "Isla Fisher") as Henley Reeves / The [High Priestess](/wiki/High_Priestess_\(Tarot_card\) "High Priestess \(Tarot card\)"): An [escapist](/wiki/Escapology "Escapology") and [stage magician](/wiki/Magic_\(illusion\) "Magic \(illusion\)"). She is also J. Daniel Atlas' former assistant and ex-lover.
  * [Morgan Freeman](/wiki/Morgan_Freeman "Morgan Freeman") as Thaddeus Bradley, an ex-magician who, for thirty years, has profited by revealing the secrets behind other magicians' tricks.
  * [Dave Franco](/wiki/Dave_Franco "Dave Franco") as Jack Wilder / [Death](/wiki/Death_\(Tarot_card\) "Death \(Tarot card\)"): A [sleight of hand](/wiki/Sleight_of_hand "Sleight of hand") illusionist, [street magician](/wiki/Street_magic "Street magic"), and a talented [impressionist](/wiki/Impressionist_\(entertainment\) "Impressionist \(entertainment\)") of other people's voices. Additionally, he is a pickpocket, and is able to [pick locks](/wiki/Lock_picking "Lock picking"). In his early twenties, Wilder is the youngest of the Four Horsemen.
  * [Michael Caine](/wiki/Michael_Caine "Michael Caine") as Arthur Tressler,[4] an insurance magnate and the Four Horsemen's sponsor.
  * [David Warshofsky](/wiki/David_Warshofsky "David Warshofsky") as FBI Agent Cowan.
  * [Michael Kelly](/wiki/Michael_Kelly_\(American_actor\) "Michael Kelly \(American actor\)") as Agent Fuller, an FBI agent who serves as Rhodes' sidekick.
  * [Common](/wiki/Common_\(rapper\) "Common \(rapper\)") as Agent Evans, Rhodes's supervisor at the FBI.
  * [José Garcia](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Garcia_\(actor\) "José Garcia \(actor\)") as Étienne Forcier, the account holder at the Crédit Républicain de Paris.
  * [Caitriona Balfe](/wiki/Caitriona_Balfe "Caitriona Balfe") as Jasmine Tressler,[4] Arthur Tressler's young wife.
  * [Elias Koteas](/wiki/Elias_Koteas "Elias Koteas") as Lionel Shrike, a magician who drowned while performing an escape trick thirty years earlier. Dylan is revealed to be his son at the end of the movie.
  * [Conan O'Brien](/wiki/Conan_O%27Brien "Conan O'Brien") as himself

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Now_You_See_Me_\(film\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

On October 25, 2011, [Summit Entertainment](/wiki/Summit_Entertainment "Summit
Entertainment") announced the release date for _Now You See Me_ for July 18,
2013.[5] On November 3, 2011, the company revealed the film's first synopsis
and teaser poster.[6]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Now_You_See_Me_\(film\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Filming")]

On January 16, 2012, shooting began in [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New
Orleans"), [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana"), which lasted until March
26, 2012.[7] Additional filming took place in [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") on February 13[8] and in [Las
Vegas](/wiki/Las_Vegas "Las Vegas") from April 9, 2012 to the following
day.[9] During filming of the scene where Henley Reeves tries to escape from a
tank of water and piranhas, [Isla Fisher](/wiki/Isla_Fisher "Isla Fisher")
came close to drowning. Fisher had become stuck and tried to alert the crew by
banging on the window she was facing, but the cast and crew did not think
anything of it because that was what the character was supposed to be doing.
She was able to untangle the chain and get out of the tank safely.[10]

The official soundtrack, titled _Now You See Me (Original Motion Picture
Soundtrack)_ , for the film was composed by [Brian
Tyler](/wiki/Brian_Tyler_\(composer\) "Brian Tyler \(composer\)") and was
released by [Glassnote Records](/wiki/Glassnote_Records "Glassnote Records")
on May 28, 2013 for physical purchase and digital download.[11] The film’s
soundtrack song “[Entertainment](/wiki/Entertainment_\(song\) "Entertainment
\(song\)")”, performed by French rock band [Phoenix](/wiki/Phoenix_\(band\)
"Phoenix \(band\)"), was featured in the film’s end credits.

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Now_You_See_Me_\(film\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Release")]

The film premiered in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") on
May 21, 2013 before its official release in the United States on May 31, 2013
by [Summit Entertainment](/wiki/Summit_Entertainment "Summit Entertainment").

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Now_You_See_Me_\(film\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Home media")]

_Now You See Me_ was released on [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") and [Blu-
ray](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc") on September 3, 2013 through
[Lionsgate Home Entertainment](/wiki/Lionsgate_Home_Entertainment "Lionsgate
Home Entertainment"). The Blu-ray release contains an extended version of the
film featuring ten additional minutes.[12] It also contains two featurettes: a
behind-the-scenes and a "History of Magic", plus 30 minutes of [deleted
scenes](/wiki/Deleted_scene "Deleted scene").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Now_You_See_Me_\(film\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Now_You_See_Me_\(film\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Box office")]

By the end of its box office run, _Now You See Me_ had grossed $117.7 million
in the U.S. and Canada and $234 million in other territories for a worldwide
total of $351.7 million, against a budget of $75 million.[3]

The film had a successful box office run, placing second behind _[Fast&
Furious 6](/wiki/Fast_%26_Furious_6 "Fast & Furious 6")_ and taking
$29,350,389 on its opening weekend from 2,925 theaters. By the end of June, it
had grossed double its production budget.[3] The film stayed in the top 10 of
the North American box office for six weeks after release.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The biggest markets in other territories were France, China, Russia, South
Korea, United Kingdom and Australia where the film grossed $25.7 million,
$22.9 million, $21.2 million $17.1 million $16.8 million and $16.1 million,
respectively.[13]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Now_You_See_Me_\(film\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Critical response")]

_Now You See Me_ received mixed reviews from critics. The most common
criticism is that various plot points were insufficiently resolved at the
film's conclusion, leaving some questions unanswered or answered unclearly
(although some suggested that this was intentional, leaving room for a
sequel).[14] On [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes") the
film has an approval rating of 49%, based on 152 reviews, with an average
rating of 5.7/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "_Now You See Me_ 's
thinly sketched characters and scattered plot rely on sleight of hand from the
director to distract audiences."[15] [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic
"Metacritic") assigned the film a score of 50 out of 100, based on 35 critics,
indicating "mixed or average reviews".[16] Audience polls conducted by
[CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore "CinemaScore") give the film a grade of "A–"
on an A+ to F scale.[17] Peter Hammond from [Movieline](/wiki/Movieline
"Movieline") wrote, "Pure summer movie magic—literally. More fun than
_[Ocean's 11](/wiki/Ocean%27s_Eleven_\(2001_film\) "Ocean's Eleven \(2001
film\)")_, _[12](/wiki/Ocean%27s_Twelve "Ocean's Twelve")_ , and
_[13](/wiki/Ocean%27s_Thirteen "Ocean's Thirteen")_ combined. You won't
believe your eyes—and that's the point."[18]

##
Sequels[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Now_You_See_Me_\(film\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Sequels")]

Main article: [Now You See Me 2](/wiki/Now_You_See_Me_2 "Now You See Me 2")

On July 3, 2013, after the box office success of the film, Lionsgate's CEO
[Jon Feltheimer](/wiki/Jon_Feltheimer "Jon Feltheimer") confirmed that there
would be a [sequel](/wiki/Sequel "Sequel") to the film with production
beginning in 2014 for an unspecified release date.[20] [Louis
Leterrier](/wiki/Louis_Leterrier "Louis Leterrier") stated that he would
return to direct the sequel;[21] however, in September 2014, it was confirmed
that [Jon M. Chu](/wiki/Jon_M._Chu "Jon M. Chu") would replace Leterrier as
director. Eisenberg, Ruffalo, Harrelson, Franco, Caine and Freeman were set to
reprise their roles for the sequel. Fisher was unable to participate because
of her third pregnancy and was replaced by [Lizzy Caplan](/wiki/Lizzy_Caplan
"Lizzy Caplan"). The film was released on June 10, 2016, titled _Now You See
Me: The Second Act_.[22] On October 2, 2014, Michael Caine said in an
interview that [Daniel Radcliffe](/wiki/Daniel_Radcliffe "Daniel Radcliffe")
would be playing his son in the film.[23] Filming began in late November.[24]
On May 22, 2015, Lionsgate revealed the details about the development of the
sequel, when CEO [Jon Feltheimer](/wiki/Jon_Feltheimer "Jon Feltheimer")
announced that they had "already begun early planning for _Now You See Me
3_."[25]
